metadata.title: Leprosy  Occupational Therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Skin/exocrine system, endocrine system, metabolic system, hemic system, lymphatic system, immune system, musculoskeletal system, nervous system, pulmonary system, reproductive system
description: Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae , an acid-fast  bacillus, that occurs in both children and adults.(1,18) M. leprae preferentially affects cooler parts of the body (e.g., skin, mucous membranes, peripheral nerves).(1) Leprosy is characterized by distinctive skin lesions and/or enlarged nerves accompanied by sensory loss.(1) Complications, i.e., the disability and morbidity associated with leprosy, result from nerve damage(2)

There are different classifications of leprosy: –WHO classification(1) -Paucibacillary (PB): no more than five skin lesions; no detectable bacilli on skin smears(1) -Includes the indeterminate, tuberculoid, and borderline tuberculoid subtypes described below(3) -Multibacillary (MB): six or more skin lesions; might be skin-smear  positive for bacilli(1) -Includes the borderline lepromatous and lepromatous subtypes described below(3) –Classification according to the Ridley-Jopling  system (named for the British researchers who developed it in the 1960s) includes six types based on skin and neurological changes as well as biopsy(1,2) -Indeterminate (I)(1,2) -Patient will have one or more hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules (circumscribed changes in skin color that are neither raised nordepressed)(1) -Patches of the skin with sensory loss; patients in the early stage of the disease have relatively preserved sensation(1) -Tuberculoid (TT)(1) -Patient will have hypopigmented macules with well-defined  demarcations; loss of sensation in these macules(1) -Nerve involvement occurs with signs such as ulnar, peroneal, and greater auricular nerves that are often palpable and visibly swollen(1) -Nerve involvement leads to lagophthalmos (inability to completely close the eyelids), keratitis (cornea inflammation), and corneal ulceration(1) -Neuriticpain(1) -Muscle atrophy, especially in the small muscles of the hand(1)  -Borderline-tuberculoid  (BT)(1,2) -The skin lesions resemble those in TT leprosy; however, the lesions are not as well-defined(2) -The number of lesions varies but is usually more than 5; the diameter is usually 10 cm or more(2) -The lesions typically are symmetrical and multiple nerves may be affected(2) -Borderline-borderline  (BB)(2) -Relatively rare and usually evolves quickly toward the Virchowian type(2) -Many foveal lesions are present with different sizes and shapes(2) -Intense involvement of nerves and positive skin smears are common(2) -Borderline-lepromatous  (BL) (Virchowian)(1,2) -Many skin lesions: macules are variable in shape and not symmetrical in distribution(2) -High bacterial load and positive bacilloscopytypical(2) -Nerve damage occurs, but not as quickly as in BB and BT forms of leprosy -Lepromatous (LL) (Virchowian)(1,2) -The disease is more symmetrical, with nondistinctive skin lesions present(1,2) -Nerve involvement occurs in the later stages, with distal extremities affected first(1) -Pure neural leprosy is a rare variant of leprosy characterized by neuropathy without evidence or history of typical skin lesions. Ulnar, tibial, and fibular nerves are most commonly affected(2) -Histoid leprosy is a rare variant of leprosy and is associated with sulfone resistance. A patient with histoid leprosy will present with superficially or deeply fixed cutaneous nodules, plaques, or pads(2)

Since the implementation of a free multidrug regimenmade available by WHO in 1981, the global incidence of leprosy has decreased significantly. In 2019 the number of new cases reported worldwide was 202,256; 34 countries reported zero new autochthonous cases (cases that originated in their own country). The COVID-19  pandemic disrupted case detections: new-case  detection reported worldwide was decreased by 37% in 2020 compared to 2019 (127,558 new cases reported and 45 countries reporting no new cases)(4) –WHO has identified 23 countries with highest rates of leprosy as priorities to reduce the number of cases including Bangladesh, Brazil, Democratic Republic of Congo, India, Indonesia, and Nepal)(26) or application of equipment Unemployment Connect the patient with appropriate social services for job placement; train the patient to perfect specific occupational tasks needed for him or her to return to gainful employmentFunctional training _ Adaptive/assistive device and equipment training(16,17) _ _ V ocational assessment and training(16) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveProgression will vary between patients based on the interventions selected and the response to treatment tasksProvide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions regarding functional activities that can be performed at home and correct use and/ or application of equipment . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures

ICD-10 codes.A30.9: leprosy, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified

In 1981 WHO recommended a multidrug regimen for treatment of leprosy (currently consists of dapsone, rifampicin, and clofazimine). Since then,WHO has providedthis regimen free of cost throughout the world(4)
presentation signs and symptoms: Leprosy can present along a continuum from simple skin lesions to severe, extensive involvement(1)

A patient with leprosy will present with any or allofthe following: –Skin lesions(1,2) –Loss of sensation; numbness(1,2) –Enlarged nerves(1) –Neuriticpain(1)  –Pain(2) –Muscle atrophy and weakness(1) –Eye problems; visual deficits(1,2)

Long-term  complications of leprosy or its treatments –Reactions -Occur during the course of leprosy; acute or subacute inflammation of the immune system, usually as a result of leprosy medication(2) -Two types of reactions: reversal reaction (RR, or type I) and erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL, or type II)(1,2,3) -RR: Most common in borderline leprosy, but can occur with any type; a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction; marked by acutely inflamed skin lesions, acute neuritis, or both(2) -ENL: An acute lepromatous reaction with generalized systemic involvement marked by the formation of painful deep nodules on the face, thighs, and arms; this is usually only seen in undiagnosed, untreated, or neglected cases of LL and BL leprosy(1) -Reactions can occur before, during, or after treatment for leprosy and can cause permanent damage (and, in the case of ENL, death).Reactions require immediate treatment with corticosteroids and/or thalidomide(2) –Disability and deformity of the hand and foot(1) -Trauma and secondary infection that can lead to loss of fingers, toes, and extremities(1) -Claw hand, claw toes(1) –Blindness resulting from corneal opacities and uveitis(1) –Cataracts(1) –Secondary amyloidosis(1) –Lucio phenomenon, a diffuse skin reaction usually seen in LL, especially in untreated cases; marked by recurrent crops of large, well-defined  ulcerative lesions. Lucio phenomenon usually occurs in the lower extremities; however, it can generalize and become fatal as a result of secondary bacterial infection and sepsis(1,2) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: The therapist should be gentle and move slowly while handling painful, swollen joints(5)
Palpation should be gentle and repeated as few times as possible
Proceed with caution when examining, palpating, or manipulating joints with skin that is fragile or broken(5)
Physician’s orders and protocol should be followed at all times(5)

Occupational therapy evaluations for patients with leprosy should utilize a client-centered  approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(5) –A client-centered  approach includes the following principles: (5) -The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about their occupational functioning -The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes -The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent -Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, and interests -When the patient can define the problems that they would like to work on, the patient also becomes a problem solver -The patient should evaluate their own performance and set personal goals

causes: leprosy is a chronic granulomat: Most transmissions require prolonged close contact with a patient with multibacillary disease. Leprosy is primarilyacquired via respiratory secretions through nasal mucosa and less commonly transmitted through injured skin(30,31,32)
Most individuals exposed to leprosy do not develop the disease because of their natural immunity(1)
pathogenesis: Preference for growth in cooler regions of the body, notably skin(31)
Widespread dissemination of the disease occurs if the respiratory tract becomes infected(1)

M. leprae multiplies slowly and therefore the incubation period of the disease can be prolonged. Symptoms may occurwithin 1 year, but can also take as long as 20 or more years; the average incubation period is 5 years(4)
When M. leprae  enters the body, a vigorous cellular immune response will result in the tuberculoid form of leprosy;minimal cellular immune response results in the lepromatous form(1)
risk factors: Age over 1 year (can present at any age; however, extremely rare in infants under 12 months of age)(1)
Close contact with an untreated person with leprosy; increases risk of contracting leprosy 8-fold(1)
Occupational exposure (for development of higher seropositivity, but not necessarily overt disease development)(25)
Contact with animals infected with M. leprae  (i.e., armadillos, especially in Texas and Louisiana)(1)
Military service or travel abroad, especially in areas with high rates of leprosy(1)

overall contraindications precautions: Leprosy is spread through respiratory droplets as well as contact with broken skin; droplet and contact precautions should be used during all sessions with a patient with leprosy, including the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) as well as a mask for respiratory protection(1,2)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

Palpation should be gentle and repeated as few times as possible
Proceed with caution when examining, palpating, or manipulating joints with skin that is fragile or broken(5)
Physician’s orders and protocol should be followed at all times(5)

Occupational therapy evaluations for patients with leprosy should utilize a client-centered  approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(5) –A client-centered  approach includes the following principles: (5) -The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about their occupational functioning -The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes -The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent -Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, and interests -When the patient can define the problems that they would like to work on, the patient also becomes a problem solver -The patient should evaluate their own performance and set personal goals

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was leprosy diagnosed in the patient? What type of leprosy does the patient have? What are the current concerns for which the patient has been referred for occupational therapy?

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical management of leprosy Reconstructive surgery might be necessary for nerve and tendon inflammation requiring transplants, the eye or eyelid, surgical release of joint contractures, and other cosmetic procedures for increased function or aesthetic purposes(1) In a prospective cohort study conducted in the Netherlands, researchers found that patients with leprosy who have hand or foot disabilities as a result of leprosy can benefit from reconstructive surgery, especially as a means of increasing both activity and social participation(6) Surgical management of deformities of the hands or feet can lead to improved function of the hand or foot in patients with leprosy(7) Decompressive surgery can treat nerve damage(1)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Multidrug treatment is standard for the treatment of leprosy(1,2)rifampicin and dapsone daily for 6 months followed by dapsone daily for 35 years(1)rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine daily for 2 years followed by dapsone daily for 10 years to indefinitely(1)600 mg rifampicin once a month and 100 mg dapsone daily for 6 months(3)600 mg rifampicin monthly, 300 mg clofazimine monthly and 50 mg daily, and 100 mg dapsone daily for 1 year(3)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Skin smears (i.e., bacillary index on slit-skin smear [BIS]) that show presence of acid-fast bacilli(1,2,22)
Detection of bacilliin the tissue by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)(1,2)
Skin biopsy (of a granuloma) stained for acid-fast  bacilli (bacillary index of granuloma [BIG])(1,2,22)
Peripheral nerve biopsy in patients with sensory loss but no skin lesions(1)
Authors of a prospective study conducted in India indicate that BIG may be better at assessing the actual bacillary load
and use of it may help to limit instances ofundertreatment  of patients(22)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Certain medications for leprosy cause reactions; document whether the patient has had a reaction or multiple reactions as well as the management of the reaction(1,2)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms as well as the location of skin lesions and nerve enlargement
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient become short of breath? If so, when? Standing? Walking? With exercise? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior history of leprosy? Family history of leprosy?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including history of falls, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Patients who are HIV-positive  with early or subclinical leprosy are more likely to develop overt leprosy; concurrent leprosy can accelerate the course of HIV infection(1)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing Kidney failure and hepatomegaly can occur as a result of secondary amyloidosis from long-standing,  untreated leprosy(3)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What are the patient’s occupations and role(s) within his or her family? -Is patient currently employed? If employed but not currently working, is he or she planning to return to work?(1)  -What leisure activities and hobbies does the patient enjoy?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be used based on patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment -In Brazil it is estimated that 23% of individuals with leprosy have some physical limitations after hospital discharge(21) -In a questionnaire and interview study conducted in Brazil, reported self-care  actions of persons with leprosy were minimal and focused on lubrication of the eyes, use of sunscreen, skin hydration, and wearing shoes
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members) -Identify the patient’s caregiver or network of support -Stigma, family abandonment, and social exclusion may be consequences of the disfiguring disabilities that can occur(21) -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -In a prospective-cohort  study conducted in Taiwan, researchers compared physical activity and QOL betweenthose in high-rise  building retirement communities and those living in ground residences. The study included 250 older adults (60+) with leprosy. Researchers found that living in a high-rise apartment environment did not decrease physical activity among these older adults and appeared to promote overall QOL with respect to psychological and environmental factors(20)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices to determine the devices that are most appropriate and will best serve their needs; incorrect use of devices can increase risk of falls –Mobility aids -Cane (single-point  and four-pronged  canes) -Walker, rolling walker -Wheelchair -Ideal for patients who are nonambulatory or unable to tolerate weight-bearing -Crutches -Hemi-walker -Handrails on stairways -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) -Rigid-soled  footwear, walking plaster casts, or dressings to treat or prevent plantar ulcers(1) –Bathroom equipment -Grab bars next to the toilet/shower -Shower chairs, bars, and/or benches -Bedside commode -Urinal at bedside -Raised toilet seat -Elevated footrest at the toilet –ADL/IADL aids -Reachers -Helping hand -Long-handled  equipment -Dressing sticks; sock aids -Specialized kitchen equipment -Personal digital assistant (PDA) -Large-print  reading material -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard -Text-to-speech  software  -Adaptive cooking equipment
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADL tasks –Tinetti Balance Scale(9) –Berg Balance Scale
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post activity; use the Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale if indicated
Monitor breathing to assist with determining fatigue and endurance levels
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesAssess cranial and peripheral nerve function –Patients with leprosy often have peripheral nerve involvement and enlarged nerves that can be palpated(2) -The nerves most affected by leprosy are the ulnar, median, common peroneal, facial, superficial radial, digital, posterior auricular, and sural nerves(8)Assess bed mobility and transfers to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activitiesa measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility(10)an 18-item,  7-level ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition(11)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –Patients with leprosy often have sensory deficits in the feet as well as foot deformities (including foot drop), reduced joint mobility in the lower extremities, and reduced ankle strength, all of which can impair gait(12) –Note use of specialty shoes, braces, or ambulatory aids for walking –If the patient is not already being seen by a physical therapist (PT), refer to physical therapy for full evaluation and treatment(12)Joint contractures occur in patients with leprosy as a result of skin and nerve damage(1) –Assess stability and mobility of the joints(1) –Leprosy can mimic the signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis in the joints; joint involvement occurs in greater than 75% of patients with leprosy(14) -For detailed information on assessment of patients with rheumatoid arthritis, see  Clinical Review…Rheumatoid ArthritisT708961Assess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities; describe quality of movement –Sensory loss as a result of nerve damage in patients with leprosy can significantly impair the ability to carry out motor tasks, especially fine motor tasks, as a result of reduced sensory feedback(15) –Reduced function of the hands is common in patients with leprosy due to bone lesions that affect the small bones of the face, hands, and feet. These lesions are caused directly by leprosy and indirectly as a result of trauma and infection imposed upon denervated tissues(1,13) -Distal absorption can result in the loss of fingers and toes; combined absorption of length and width of bone often affects the metatarsophalangeal joints(1) –Bilateral ulnar nerve involvement is suggestive of leprosy;(3) typical ulnar nerve deformities can develop (e.g., clawing)a seven-part  test designed to assess the level of unilateral hand function in everyday functional tasks(15)predicts the ability of the patient to perform functional activities requiring the use of three-jaw  chuck prehension(15)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities; do not perform MMT with contracted muscles or muscles with tone and coordination issues(15) –Muscle weakness or motor abnormalities usually occur after significant sensory loss has occurred as a result of nerve infiltration(3,8) –Assess upper extremities and document any abnormalities; use dynamometer to evaluate grip strength bilaterally; assess pinch strength using a pinch meter
observation inspection palpation includi: Document the number, location, and appearance of skin lesions(1)
Note the presence of enlarged nerves that can be palpated(2)
Patients with leprosy have an increased risk of trauma and ulcers to the feet due to lack of sensation(16)
Note any signs of skin breakdown, especially if the patient has been bedbound for a prolonged period -A turning protocol to shift the patient’s weight can reduce the risk of pressure ulcers
Reduced sensation in the feet increases risk of injury and ulcerations of the foot
relevant tests and measures.posture: Poor posture can affect the patient’s ability to complete occupational tasks such as feeding, dressing, oral care, transfers, and meal preparation –Document static/dynamic posture in supine, sitting, and standing throughout a variety of tasks according to weight-bearing  precautions -Note posture with/without adaptive equipment
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess ROM of the upper extremities using goniometerAssess safety and ability to perform ADLs hair, upper and lower body dressing, managing clothing, using the toilet, applying makeup or shaving the face, bathing, eating –Lack of sensation in the limbs can increase risk of injury during ADLs(13) –The FIM, the Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS), the Disability Rating Index (DRI), the Katz Index of Independence in Activities of Daily Living, and the Barthel Activities of Daily Living Index are appropriate standardized measures for ADLs in patients with leprosy –For high-functioning  patients, assess IADLs such as driving (including car transfers), meal preparation, shopping, and housework -Lawton and Brody Instrumental Activities of Daily Living Scale -Includes items related to using the telephone, using public transportation, shopping, meal preparation, housework, and medication and money management
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory loss occurs as a result of peripheral and small dermal nerve damage in leprosy(2) –Assess light touch, pinprick, position sensation (proprioception and kinesthesia), vibration, and temperature –The Semmes-Weinstein  Monofilaments Test measures cutaneous sensory perception thresholds with different monofilaments, each representing a unique amount of force. This test is appropriate for the evaluation of light touch–deep pressure sensibility, with good reliability and validity(15)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –QOL -Even after patients with leprosy are cured of the disease, disability and social stigma can create significant psychosocial problems -Authors of a literature review found that the stigma of having leprosy can result in a decrease in QOL, including loss of occupation, social ties, and reputation; difficulty finding a life partner; divorce; and discrimination. They found that these impacts oftenprevent individuals from coming forward to receive treatment and the appropriate therapy(27) -The Short Form Health Survey (SF-36)  evaluates overall independence, emotional and mental health, limitations to previous roles, and social status  -The Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) evaluates function through evaluation at baseline and status throughout treatment, utilizing the patient’s direct input -The COPM allows patients to identify goals in therapy that are personally meaningful; it is useful as part of a client-centered  approach to therapy
relevant tests and measures.perception: Patients with leprosy can have involvement of the eye(s) and deficits of vision as a result of the disease(1) –Immediate detection and treatment of eye problems are important for maintaining vision and function of the eye(1) –Note both visual and auditory abilities and deficits; refer to reports from audiologist and/or ophthalmologist, as availableOccupational Therapy ;T708963
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Note patient’s ability to communicate and level of arousal as well as memory, attention, problem solving, and orientation to person, place, time, and situation –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is appropriate for patients with leprosy

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The goals of occupational therapy for patients with leprosy are to increase independence in ADLs/IADLs, assist with vocational assessment and training, provide and train patient to use assistive devices and equipment as indicated, and educate the patient regarding the disease process.(16)A multidisciplinary approach is necessary to meet the many needs of a patient with leprosy.(1)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out the following diagnoses when the patient undergoes a workup for leprosy Systematic lupus erythematosus (SLE)(1) Rheumatoid arthritis(1) Sarcoidosis(1) Lymphomatoidgranulomatosis(1) Cutaneous leishmaniasis(1) Peripheral neuropathy (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome)(1) Fungal infections(1) Post-kala-azar  dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL)(24)
prognosis: Without treatment, leprosy can lead to significant disability and even death(1,2)
Relapse is < 1% in multibacillary and just over 1% in paucibacillary cases(1)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physical therapist for ambulation, gait training, strengthening/ROM program, etc.(1,12) Ophthalmologist for vision testing and intervention as indicated(1) Orthopedic surgeon(1) Case management or social worker(1) Psychiatrist or psychologist to address psychosocial needs, including psychological trauma and social stigma(1) Dentist for teeth cleaning and/or oral health management
other considerations: Because the medications for leprosy work slowly and need to be taken for prolonged periods, compliance is often poor, leading to recurrence of leprosy(1,2)
Authors of systematic review and meta-analysis  found that leprosy rates were elevated in patients with medication-induced immunosuppression who have rheumatological diseases(29)
treatment summary: The occupational therapy department at the National Leprosy Centre in Malaysia (formerly the Sungai Buloh Leprosarium) states that patients with leprosy are referred to their department for:  –ADL assessment(16) -OTs provide ADL training for ADLS and IADLS such as cooking and gardening(16) -Cooking and gardening utensils are adapted for those patients with deformities(16) -Mugs are made of special material that does not conduct heat (due to the lack of sensation, patients with leprosy are at increased risk for burns because they cannot feel how hot an object is before touching it)(16) –vocational assessment and training(16) -The OTs assess the patient’s needs and refer for further training in fields that are best suited for the patient’s current abilities and vocational goals(16) -A report is sent to a social welfare office to provide guidance or to find appropriate employment for the patient(16) –special shoes(16) -Shoes for patients with leprosy are specially designed to provide even weight distribution on the sole surface, save the feet from shearing stresses, and provide adequate support for the ankle(16) –artificial limb fabrication(16) -Artificial limbs are fitted and provided to leprosy patients in this facility free of charge(16) -For detailed information on amputation and artificial limbs, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

ADL/IADL training(13) –Lack of sensation in the limbs can increase risk of injury during ADLs/IADLs(13) –The first step in training a patient with leprosy in safe and independent performance of ADLs and IADLs is education about the disease itself and what causes limb deformities and absorption of the digits (i.e., neglect of the disease, improper care, trauma, and infection)(13) –When the patient performs their ADLs, it is of the utmost importance to protect their digits and limbs from trauma as well as protect the skin from additional lesions or ulcers(13) –Teach the patient practical ways of preserving their limbs when performing ADLs and IADLs(13) -For example, learning to cook without sustaining burns by having heatproof handles on pots, using gloves, and planning meals carefully ahead of time(13) –Additionally, the patient should be taught to develop a habit of checking their limbs for injury after the completion of tasks and quickly cleaning and dressing any wounds(13) –Train the patient to use visual feedback, rather than sensory feedback, to keep the hands safe from injury(7)

Disability prevention and deformity care –For patients with leprosy, it is extremely important that proper self-care  is implemented to prevent as much disability as possible due to nerve and/or joint swelling, eye problems, and wound and skin infection(17) –As part of the therapy program the OT should educate the patient on proper self-care  and determine that they can properly carry out the tasks(17) –The types of care needed specifically for this patient population include:(17) -skin care -wound care -joint care -swelling care -eye care -nerve care –Proper self-care  practices for patients with leprosy include: -soaking, scrubbing, lubricating oil, and dressing wounds(17) -correct and regular use of assistive and protective devices(17) -cleaning and dressing any ulcer or crack in the skin(17) -joint protection strategies(17) -Respect pain(5)  -Maintain muscle strength(5) -Maintain joint ROM; use each joint in its most stable and anatomical/functional plane(5) -Avoid positions of deformity(5) -Use the strongest joints possible for each task(5) -Use the correct pattern of movement in activities(5) -Avoid prolonged static positions(5) -Avoid participation in activities that can’t be stopped immediately if they become too stressful(5) -Balance activity with adequate rest(5) -Reduce the force and effort used in all tasks (with assistive devices as needed)(5) . maintenance or prevention: Early detection and treatment of leprosy can help suppress infectiousness, decrease disability, and control the spread worldwide(26)

Authors of an integrative literature review evaluated the effectiveness of leprosy educational programs with adolescents(28) Nine studies were included They found that the leprosy education programs improved the knowledge of the adolescents, but more research is needed to evaluate their effectiveness in changing behaviors and practices WHO supports the use of educational programs, stating that they help to decrease false concepts, stigmas, and prejudices associated with the disease

In India, a “block-level  awareness campaign” was shown to increase detection of new leprosy cases(23) Active surveillance was performed via a house-to-house  survey and screening for leprosy Information, education, and communication activities around leprosy were also done both before and during the surveillance activities

Timely diagnosis and treatment of leprosy(before nerve damage has occurred)with multidrug therapy is the most effective way to prevent disability associated with the disease(18,19) In a study conducted in Brazil with data from 368 patients with leprosy, researchers found that the greatest risk for long-term disability and neurological worsening posttreatment was disability at the time that treatment was initiated(19)
There is some evidence that the use of the bacillus Calmette-Guérin  (BCG) vaccine in areas of high incidence around the world will aid in prevention of leprosy(1,2)

Preventing permanent disability in patients with leprosy requires periodic measurement of neural impairment by the physician, early and appropriate management of reactions, use of proper footwear, and proper care of the eyes, hands, and feet throughout a patient’s lifetime(2) Rate of relapse for PB forms of leprosy is just over 1% and for MB forms is less than 1%. Patients should be followed monthly during treatment and every 3 to 6 months for 5–10  years following the completion of treatment (1) Preventing hand injury and/or infection is extremely important to avoid permanent disability and deformity(7)
To maintain gains of therapeutic interventions and continue to make gains, the patient should continue exercises found effective and well-tolerated
patient education: It is important to educate the patient on the slow course of the disease and to emphasize the importance of finishing the full course of drug treatment even after symptoms improve(1)
